div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.

div.p: Mulazim Awil Mohamed Erfel of Sananoud seized so okes of bashish in a Greek's house in that town on the 30th ult

div.head: Alexandria Tramway Extension.
div.p: The Municipality hare authorised the Alexandria Tram way Company to proceed with the extension of their line from Mex to Agami

div.head: The Cairo Strikkes.
div.p: Forty-six ont of fifty-five rioters arrested during the Cailo strikes have been sentenced to various terms of imprisonment, varying from a week to a month. Seven cases remain to be tried and two have been acquitted.

div.head: Faste and Feaste.
div.p: The Bourses are closed today, it being the Good Friday of the Orthodox Church, arid will not re-open until Tuesday, Monday being | both Greek Easter Monday and Shem el Nessim. The Banks are also closed to-day and will ciose again on Monday.

div.head: Steam Tug for Quarantine Service.
div.p: The order for the new steam-tug to be used at Tor by the Quarantine Board has been i placed with Messrs Ashton and Kilner, Adiniralty builders of Poole, Dorsetshire, introduced by Messrs. James Carrall, Wilcocks and Company, of Alexandria.
The Brindisi Mall.

The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O., Alex. andria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday for ordinary correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p.m. on Saturday for parcels.

div.head: Sacred Concert
div.p: A sacred- concert organised by Mr. J.! Schwindl for the benefit of a work of charity, is to be given on Ascension Day, the 9th inst. at the Lazarists Church, commencing at 6 p.m. Tickets are on sale at Hugo Hackh's, L. Schuler's, F. Lifonti's, and G. Romanelli's, at the price of P.T. 30 each.

div.head: Alexandria Harbour.
div.p: The work of constructing the new breakwater, which will extend from the end of the t qnarantine port breakwater in a direction N. N. W. 1 W. has been commenced. A gast buoy showing a green fixed light has been placed near the spot where the work will terminate.

div.head: Post Office Savings Banks.
div.p: During the month of March L.E. 52,907 were deposited in the Post Office Savings Bank, the number of new depositors during that time being 1,510, which with 62,605 | depositors remaining on the 28th of February makes 64,115 for the month's receipts, with a total deposit of L.E. 409,064 € The sums" withdrawn during March totalled L.E. 43,157. .
Royal Roumanlan Express Steamer Service.

The S.s. Imperatol Trajan leaving Alexandria for Constantza on May 10 will call | exceptionally at the island of Rhodos. The fares fixed are very moderate and we can 1 recommend those who intend going to Rhodos. 1 to avail themselves of the present favorable opportunity. The duration of the voyage will [1 be only 18 hours. For all particulars apply to: the Agents : Wm H Müller and Co., 16|| Sesostris-street and Otto Sterzing, Opera Square, Cairo.
Mena House

Mena House hotel is still open and there are a considerable number of visitors and residents remaining for this month. The weather is deliciously cool and fresh and golf,croquet and tennis are still being playd. Special attention having been paid during the whole season to the mosquitoes, Mena is entirely free from them, which adds greatly to the comfort of visitors, as mosquito curtains may be dispensed with. The golf course is still in good playing condition, and golf players will be glad to hear: that there is a possibility of an arrangement being come to between the Government and the Nungovich Hotel Co. whereby these famous links at the base of the Pyramids may be preserved for all time. The large marbleswimming bath is also open to non-residents.

div.head: The Cheap Houses Movement.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon an official meeting of the Special Municipal Committee charged with the qnestion of the erection of cheap houses in Alexandria, was held at the Municipality. Mr. Chataway was in the chair and the other members present included Diettrich Bey, Dr. Gottschlich, Messrs. Rieti and Fenderl, Cavalieri Ronci, President of the Tenants Commission, Mr. Frederick Cree; and the two architects of the Tenants Commission also attended by.invitation, Messrs. Hornbonstel and Crum. bold. The new plans of the economical houses were submitted to the meeting by Mr Cavalieri Ronci, and were approved in principle by Diettrich Bey and Dr. Gottschlich. The plans will be submitted to the plenary meeting of the Municipal Commission on Wednesday next. The special committee has authorised Mr. Cavalieri Ronci to prepare the estimate of cost of the scheme.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner Bulgarian sailed this morning from Malta, for this port, calling at at Migrata (Barbary).
The Cunard 8.8. Brescia sailed for Liverpool yesterday afternoon with a full cargo, including 1,758 bales cotton and 15,087 bags onions,

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
EGYPTIAN UNREST.
div.p: The following questions have recently been asked in the House of Commons :

Mr Fell asked the Secretary for Foreign be Affairs if his attention had been called to the ti language used by certain of the newspapers in b Egypt in their references to the authorities and the Government, and whether he would consider the advisability of modifying the freedom of the Press, to the advantage of Egypt and its Government | Sir E Grey : I must refer the hon, member to Chapter IV of Lord Cromer's Annual Report for 1906. It is not proposed to alter the policy there advocated.

div.head: THE EVACUATION OF THE
BAHR-EL-GHAZAL
div.p: Mr. Londsdale asked the Secretary of State of for Foreign Affairs whether he would state the te date upon which the Congolese troops evacnated the Sudanese Bahr-el-Ghazal, in accord- of ance with the terms of the Anglo-Belgian d Convention.
Sir E. Grey said instructions were sent on ir April 8 He was not aware whether thosem instructions had been fully carried out
Mr Lonsdale inquired as to the reason for co the delay in evacuation by the Congolese be troops.
Sir E Grey replied that he had previously u stated that the actual date must depend to a|M certain extent upon climatic considerations si and the period of the year.

div.head: MISSIONARIES IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: Mr. J. Robertson asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether Christian missions in the southern portion of the Sudan were being actively promoted by the Government there, notwithstanding that the population of the northern portion of that province was declared by Lord Cromer to be almost entirely Moslem, and that Christian propaganda was there expressly forbidden, excepting in Khartoum ; whether, in view of the danger of this artificial division of the Sudan into two contrastedt portions, and in order to obviate the risks off sanguinary conflict amongst a people just for emerging from barbarism, he wonld direct that the official promotion of Christian missions in the Southern Sudan should cease.

Sir E. Grey : I have no information beyond li that contained in Lord Cromer's annual report for 1906, and in previous reports which have cl been published. And I am not aware of any It circumstances which reqnire such intervention as the hon. member suggests

div.head: GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS
div.p: Mr. J. M. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether a number of te officials had been dismissed, or invited to J resign, from the service of the Egyptian Goy- | 10 ernmentfor no reason of misconduct, but solely on account of their differing from the British Agency on points of administration ; and whether he had sanctioned such proti ceedings,
Sir E. Grey, - I am not aware of any such w circumstances. \ Mr. J. M. Robertson asked whether theo right hon. gentleman would make inqniries asp to whether such cases had occurred.

Sir E. Grey.—The question of the hon. gentleman seems to imply a general censure on appointments and dismissals in the Egyptian service. I have no reason to suppose that such a question is justified, and there is not reason for me to make inquiries.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers held yesterday morning at Abdeen palace under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive approved of the following:
1. A decree appointing Mohamed Bey Sidki the President of the Cairo native Tribunal,
Counsellor at the Native Court of Appeal in | the place of Hussein Bey Rushdi. promoted | Director General of the Wakfs Administration, | and approving a long list of promotions and
transfers among the Judges of the native 1. Bench to follow upon this appointment.

2 A note from the British Agency asking | for the raising of the annual contribution of the Egyptian Government towards the ex: penses of the Army of Occupation from L.E. 145,000 to LE. 150,000 in consequence of the increased cost of living in the country:
3. A decree appointing M. Laloi, President T of Chamber at the Court of Appeal at Algiers, to the Cairo Mixed Tribunal of the First Instance in the place of M. Bourgueil, resigned.

4. A decree investing the chief veterinary | inspector of the Alexandria Municipality and bis assistants with the powers of the judicial police in respect to contraventions committed | against veterinary regulations.

div.head: FIRE AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Thursday. A serions fire broke out this morning at the Quarantine inflammable store situated at the Suez Docks, which was in a very short time completely burnt down. In spite of the prompt assistance of the Suez fire brigade, water boats etc. nothing whatever was sayed from the store, which collapsed. The conflagration * was, however, extingnished with great trouble | I understand that the value of stores destroyed is about £1,500.

div.head: JUDICIAL ADVISER'S REPORT
COMMITTEE OF SURVEILLANCE.
div.p: (CONTINUED) The committee of surveillance is, and always as been, a purely advisory body, but the fact that its inspectors are the officers who are rought into direct contact with the judicial ork of the tribunals had had a strongly sintegrating effect on the general organisa on of the Ministry, and while the routine
ministrative work had continued to be perormed by the native directorate, the inspectorte was the only office competent to advise as

the distribution of the judicial staff, or to e utilised in connection with amendments in he judicial machinery. Further, the senior native inspector, although a magistrate, and only delegated to the committee of surveillance, ad gradually become in reality & permanent official of the Ministry, whilst his functions ended more and more in practice to encroach upon those theoretically reserved to the director f the native bureaux. Moreover, this latter irectorate, which embraced practically everyhing except mixed tribunals and financial aspection of registries (viz., native tribunals, nehkemehs, personnel, accounts, translation, vildings, etc.), was far too unwieldy and overed too wide a field to permit of the work eing effectively supervised by one man ; and redistribution, on a more rational basis, was urgently required. The internal services of the linistry have, therefore, been re-organised, ince the retirement of Hanna Bey Bacoum md the transfer of Osman Bey Mortada, on a boting more in harmony with the actual istribution of business in practice. The Tinistry has, consequently, been divided into our separate directorates each with its own clearly determined sphere of action, viz. (1) irectorate of mixed tribunals, (2) directorate f native tribunals, (3) directorate of melheehs, and (4) directorate of personnel and ccounts.
REVISION OF THE CODES

From the Adviser's report it is evident that the present code of civil procedure is unsatisactory in various respects and chiefly by the act that it affords so little guidance to litigants T assistance to the courts, in the performance f the primordial task of defining at an early tage of the action the issues or precise points

dispute between the parties. The reform of the Procedure Code was commenced at the lose of 1905. As a preliminary step, several of he judges were invited to submit to the sinistry memoranda of a general character ndicating the respects in which, in their opinion, change was desirable. The next step was to summon a small Commission (See O.J., Iarch 17th 1906), which began early in 1906 o meet once or twice a week at the Ministry of justice to consider the various proposals emboded in the memoranda above mentioned, as well as certain broad questions of policy subnitted to it by the Ministry. Incidentally, it was made known to the legal profession that he Code of Procedure was under consideration, nd that suggestions and criticisms would be welcomed. A certain number of detailed memranda were received, chiefly from members f the Bar At least one of the vernacular apers published articles of a technical characer on desirable reforms, and these also were considered by the Commission. The Coinmission uspended its meetings at the beginning of the racation, and the second stage of the work was aken in hand last autumn. This consists in he preparation of a detailed draft, on the ines laid down by the Commission This draft s now in course of preparation by several hands, but it is to be anticipated that some eonsiderable time must elapse before it will be ready for further consideration. The amount of detailed work which it involves is considerable.

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
A FALSE CHARGE.
div.p: Under the above heading the editor of "AlWatan" writes:-"An astounding piece of news was circulated last week by the Opposition Press--if we may borrow the name. A false charge against the Ministers of his Highness was agreed upon by "Al-Moayad," "Al-Lewa," and "Al-Minbar" published on the same mlay and in the same tone. According to these Opposition newspapers the Ministers were busy calling upon the notables of Cairo and persuading them to sign documents and subscribe to funds for honouring Lord Cromer. They all agreed in considering this action tantamount to felony and treachery, Asserting that the unhappy Ministers were met with refusal and left with failure everywhere!

We had the honour of calling upon two separate Ministers on Wednesday last and were told by both gentlemen that the story was a bare-faced fabrication without a shadow of truth. It was pointed out to us by one Minister that neither Lord Cromer would favour such conduct por he, the Minister, would condescend to call on any one and ask him to sign or subscribe The other Minister wished these Opposition papers to name any person called upon by one of the Ministers or spoken to on the subject of Lord Cromer, if they knew of any. In both cases we were fully authorised to give the most explicit and open dementi to the false charge published at the instance of the source that has always been hostile to the British Agency and the Egyptian Ministry alike.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
IMPORTANT JUDGMENT.
div.p: | The full Court of Judges of the British | Supreme Consular Court has just given its decision on a point of law of great interest and importance to British subjects holding real property in Egypt. -

The late Dr. W. Torrey Grant died unmarried and intestate, leaving some real property near Mansourah. His nearest relations | were a sister of the full blood, married to Mr. Morice, and two sisters and one brother of the half blood, all three being minors. By English law the sister of the full blood would be entitled to the whole of the real estate left by deceased, whereas, by the rules of succession according to local law, half of the realty would go to the other three persons. The matter came before the Mixed Courts, and was referred to the British Consular Court for a decision as to who were the persons entitled to inherit the property. | Judge Piggott, before whom the case was brought, in Egypt, felt that the question was so important that it should come before the full Court, and he referred the parties accordingly. The case was tried by the Judges who assembled in Constantinople on the 1st and 2nd April last; Counsel having to travel to that city in order to pot their arguments before the Court. Mr. A. S. | Preston, on behalf of Mrs. Morice, who had taken out letters of administration, contended that upon the construction of Article 77 of the Mixed Civil Code "the Laws of the Nation' I to which deceased "belonged" should be applied, and argued his case upon this theory.

Mr. Reginald Silley, on behalf of the three minors, contended that the "laws of the Nation" must be interpreted in a wide and general sense, so as to include the principles applied in English Courts, and that therefore the "lex loci" must be applied ; he contended that the rules of succession were not determined by the Mixed Codes, but must be looked for in the general body of Ottoman law, and accordingly that Mussulman law must govern the question.
Eventnally, after for some weeks considering their decision, the Judges decided that Mussul| man law must apply.

div.head: THE CROMER DEMONSTRATION.
div.p: All the available space for the meeting in honour of Lord Cromer on Saturday next has now been allotted, and the committee greatly | regret their inability to give tickets to the many
hundreds of applicants for whom it is impos| sible to find places. The mass of correspondence
has been so great that it has been impossible | to answer each application individually.
A special train will leave Cairo for Alex| andria after the meeting at 8.30 p.m (not 8
p.m. as announced yesterday) and arrive at | Alexandria at 12-10 am A dining-car will be | attached to the train and the train will be composed of first class carriages only.

div.head: ANOTHER NEW COMPANY.
CREDIT SOUDANAIS.
div.p: The issue of the Credit Soudanais, a limited company with a capital of Frs. 5,000,000, will | take place at Paris, London, Cairo, Alexandria, and Khartoum on the 6th, 7th, and 8th inst The administrators of this company are Messrs. Lebon, president of the Administrative Council of the Credit Foncier et Agricole d'Algerie, at Paris ; the Hon Arthur Stanley, Member of Parliament ; Carton de Wiart ; Zafiropoulo, Marseilles banker ; Colonel James ; R.P. Gordon; C. B. Karl Hasselbach : and A. Bonnel de Mézières. Mr. Robert, who has resigned the position of secretary to the French | Chamber of Commerce of Alexanndria, has | been called to Paris to an important post in the administration of this company.

div.head: NATIONALIST AND M. P'S.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes :

"The astounding statements made by "Al Watan" and "Al Zaher" on the subject of the subventions granted to certain Members of the British Parliament by the persons who J are supplying the funds of the Egyptian Nationalist Party has caused much comment in Cairo. It is said that if proof be forthcoming some interesting results may engne and it is stated that some remarkable facts have already come to light, but whether they bear out the
contention of the above mentioned newspapers - I cannot say."
As we mentioned when these charges were - first made in "Al Watan," we refused to give
any credence to them and will persist in our 3 scepticism until proof be adduced. On the , other hand it may be urged that if the Irish t | Nationalist Parliamentary Party in the House
of Commons are openly supported by funds o from sympathisers in the United States, why
shonld not that type of Radical, who is a friend of every country but his own, consider it not beneath his dignity as a member of the
House of Commons to be subventioned by a Orientals!

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: OPEN LAWN TENNIS TOURNAMENT

The finals of the ladies' doubles and men's d doubles will be played this afternoon at 4.16 dand 5 o'clock, and the finals of the mixed doubles and men's singles will be played tomorrow, when the distribution of prizes will take place.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: Wo do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex
pressed by our correspondenta, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necesary limitsfroe discussion.
- SABM EL NESBJM.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
Sir,-Referring to the statement in your | paper of to-day respecting the rumours going | the round that the natives are preparing to

commit disturbances on Shem el Nessim day, I | don't you think that the best way to prevent such an occurrence (granting that the rumours are correct) would be that the whole troops of the Army of Occupation stationed in Alex. andria should perform a march round the town, as has been done on other occasions. This would in a way frighten the natives and show them that there are troops here to prevent them, as in many cases the natives think that the number of British soldiers stationed in Alexandria does not surpass two | dozen.--Yours etc.
VISITOR. · Alexandria, May 2, 1907.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS.
div.p: The report for the year ended December 31 states that the Government decree, which on taccount of the cattle plague closed all markets
to horned cattle, was withdrawn on November 20, 1905. Since that date, in consequence of
small local outbreaks of the disease, markets 1 within certain areas have been repeatedly
closed and reopened by order of the Government Sanitary Department. The stringent measures
which have been adopted will, it is hoped, e speedily prove effective, as all fresh outbreaks
of the disease have been confined to the areas e first effected. The total gross receipts from all "sources are £36,773, Of this amount £23,159 I was derived from the cattle markets, £12,077

from the general markets, £658 from the abatxstoirs, and £877 from sundry other sources, e | The working expenses have been kept at the e | lowest figure consistent with efficient official e supervision. The expense of working the y markets during 1906 was £19,765, as compared Il with £17,908 for the year 1905. After meet gling all administration and working expenses |- | the net revenue from all sources for 1906 | amounts to £17,008, which with the balance brought forward from 1905 gives a total of £19,907 to be dealt with. After payment of an inturim dividend in October, 1906, on the
Ordinary Shares of the company, which nabsorbed £3,738, and meeting all fixed charges,
8 including the annual premia and reserves for y the amortisation of the share and debenture y capital £4712 and debenture interest £4,800, - | a balance of £6,656 remains available. Of this
sum Government, under the terms of the e concession, can claim £623, leaving for the

company £6,033. The directors recommend <- the payment of a further dividend of 4 per 8 cent. on the Ordin ary Shares, making 7 per tcent, for the year, which will absorb £4,988, elelving a balance of £1,045 to be carried ne forward.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAY COMPANY.
div.p: The general manager of the above company issued invitations to the representatives of the local press, Government officials and a number | of friends for the inauguration of the new a extension of the Shoubra line which has just
been completed, and the party proceeded to the tramway kiosk at Midan Bab el-Hadid on Tuesday afternoon by a special train of
cars at 3 o'clock for Shoubra village, where the ill extension ends, and where the guests took at steamer for Rod-el-Farag and thence back to | town, refreshments being served on the steamer.
The new line, or rather prolongation, starts from the caracol and is 2 kilometres and 700
metres long, the total length from the central ng tramway station at Ataba el. Hadra to Shoubra h village being close on 7 kilometres and the ne time occupied from end to end being 37

minutes, whilst the charge is only 5 milli mes for the entire journey. This extension will undoubtedly greatly benefit the whole of the district and caase a demand for residential buildings, as the neighbourhood is healthy and cool in summer.

The Tramway Company has also completed Al the laying of the rails across the bridge that of joins Rodah Island to Ghizeh and is now layTsing them over the smaller bridge at the Old 90 Cairo end. The new line that will cross Rodah un from Cairo to the Pyramids will be ready for mt opening as soon as the bridges are officially ng inaugurated next antumn. At present the
| Public Works Departments are busy making y the approaches to the main bridge at Ghizeh
and these are not expected to be ready before Ts October. The Tramway Company have ordered
ten new first-class cars for the Pyramids line as the present number running is not deemed
sufficient to cope with the increased traffic nr resulting from the new Rodah Island line.
The extension of the Khalig line from its
present terminus at Mawardy to the native se cemeteries at Imam El Chaffey, a distance of
1,100 metres, will shortly be completed and ny opened to traffic.

div.p: The adjourned general meeting of the Alexandria Cricket Club will take place on Tuesday 7th May at the British Consulate at 6.30 p.m.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Fadi Pasha has left for Europe,
Thurneyssen Pasha will arrive in Alexandria | from Cairo to-morrow and will reside during the summer months at Ramleh.
Baron de Grunau, secretary at the German Diplomatic Agency, is leaving shortly, for Europe on a six months' holiday.
Judge Keman's transfer from the Mixed Tribunals of First Instance of Mansourah to Cairo dates from Wednesday last.
Mr. Richmond, director-general of Towns and State Buildings, who is going on two months' holiday, will, on his return, replace Mr. Perry, who goes on leave on July,.
Mr. Francois Loloi, who succeeds Mr. Pranières as judge of the Mixed Tribunals will | arrive in Cairo this week from Algiers, where he was president of the Court of Appeal,
Major Vernon Jarvis, appointed inspector of police, has been succeeded as chief of the | traffic by Bimbashi Archer.

Captain A. J. Williams, Army Veterinary Corps, has been selected for service with the Khedive's army. Captain Williams, who has latterly served at Norwich, had a great deal of experience in the South African War. He was with the Thorneycroft's Mounted Infantry on the road to Kimberley, and was senior veterinary officer to the Sixth Division. He was present at the actions of Paardeberg, | Poplar Grove and Driefontein ; the operations generally in Orange River Colony, the Transvaal and Cape Colony (Queen's medal with four clasps King's medal with two clasps).

The editor of the French edition of the "Egyptian Standard,"M. Saint-Ogan, has resignel hispost. He only arrived in Egypt a few weeks ago when the newspaper was started It will be remembered that at the inanguration of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's European newspapers, M. Saint-Ogan created some sensation by announcing that he had come to Egypt "to save the honour of France". He has evidently given up the task as a bad job so far as working for such a noble object under the aegis of the Apostle of Egyptian Nationalism is concerned.

Mr. Anatole France, the celebrated French academician and author of "Thais" and "Syl. vestre Bonnard" is touring in the East. At present Mr. France is at Constantinople and it is possible that he will visit Egypt shortly.
Mr. Almagia, having completed the works of the Eastern Quay and handed them over to the Minicipality, has given a sum of £400 to the Orwa Al Woska and £100 to Lady Cromer's Hospital.
The selection of Sir Eldon Gorst to succeed Earl Cromer has involved certain changes at | the Foreign Office, and the Secretary of State
for Foreign Affairs has appointed Mr. Louis t|Malet, C.B., to be an Assistant Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, in succession to Sir, Eldon.

div.head: "ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION.
SECTION COTONNIERE.
div.p: RESUME DES REPONSES REQUES EN AVRIL 1907. N°173
D'une façon générale, les ensemencements pour la prochaine récolte sont de 15 à 20 jours en retard.
Ceux faits de bonne heure, et qui sont cette année de beaucoup les moins importants, ont

u à souffrir des in empéries du mois de Mars et ont donné lieu à des réensemencements, parfois. repétés, dans la plupart des districts ; ceux | tardifs, par contre, ont bien réussi, quoique la plante, par suite de la température trop fraiche, n'ait pas encore atteint un développement normal.-Elle est toutefois saine et pourrait, avec de bonnes chaleurs," regagner le temps perdu. | L'augmentation de l'acréage dans la BasseEgypte paraît être insignifiante.
Comme toujours, le Mit-Afifi prédomine ; $mais dans la Gharbieh et la Galioubiệh surtout, | les cultures de Nuhari et de Ioannovich sont bien plus étendues que celles de l'année pag
sée. Il y a aussi une légère augmentation sur be l'Abassi.
L'eau est suffisante pour le moment.
HAUTE-EGYPTE ET FAYOUM.
Les renseignements reçus de la Haute Egypte sont presque unanimes à admettre une augof mentation d'acréage de 20 à 25%. d! La plante est stine, mais il y a aussi du retard par suite de la fraicheur..
On estime à 10% de la superficie cultivée | l'étendue des terrains qui ont do être resgemés. L'eau est assez abondante
Le Président,
C. de Tschudi. Alexandrie, le 30 Avril 1907.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPHE PATHE.
div.p: C'est le mardi 7 Mai qu'aura lieu à 6 h. 1/2 précises l'inau iiration de la nouvelle SALLE PATHÉ, rue de l'ancienne Bourse, à proximits du Telégraphe Anglais, dans le plus beau et plus frais quartier de la ville. Il est impossible de rêver salon plus coquet, plus luxueux que ce nouvel établissement. M. de Lagarenne a véritablement fait des merveilles. Il a importé à Alexandrie ce genre inconnu jusqu'à ce jour des Salons de spectacle des grands Boulevards de Paris. Richesse de la décoration, de la lumière, des teintures, confortable absolu des places de toutes classes, tout y est et le Cinématographe Pathé déjà sacré par les amateurs comme modèle du genre va devenir, le rendez-vous de tout ce que la Société Alexandrine compte de plus distingué et deplus sélect. En outre le programme d'ouverture sera particulièrement soigné comme du reste celui qu'on donne cette semaine rue Toussoun pour la clôture.
Circulaire H, De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Jeudi 2 Mai 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 3 1/4 pour cent. Hier, le Stock Exchange est resté fermé à l'occasion du ler Mai.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est resté immobile à 720. La Banque d'Athènes a encore avancé de 1 franc à 127.

Ici, bien qu'on apparence la situation reste dans le " statu quo ", la tendence du marché n'en devient pas moins de jour en jour meilleure. Ce matin, le nombre des transactions conclues en corbeille s'est élevé à 18; on a négocié des Union Foncière, des Gharbith Land, des Oasis, des fondateurs Epargne Immobilière et Express Nile, des Walker and Meimarachi, des Constructions, des obligations Crédit Foncier, etc. Il y a, en outre, beaucoup de demandes de titres hors Bourse, naturelle. ment quelque peu au-dessous des prix de compensation, ce qui n'en est pas moins un bon indice,

Une amélioration marquée se manifeste, d'autre part, à Alexandrie. Toutes les Agences ont payé hier les différences résultant des compensations ; une seule petite maison qui éprouvait des difficultés a réussi à les surmonter ce matin. On peut dég, lors s'attendre à ce que la liquidation de là-bas se fasse tout aussi bien qu'au Caire, et ce d'autant plus que la reprise du coton semble appelée à contribuer à l'obtention de ce résultat.

On attribue aux Comités des Corporations des agents de change du Caire et d'Alexandrie le projet de patronner la création d'une Banque | Auxiliaire de la Bourse, dont l'objet serait de prêter au marché, dans les circonstances diffi ciles, l'aide qu'il n'a pas jusqu'à présent trouvée auprès des établissements de crédit exigtants.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 26 Avril, l'intéressant passage suivant :

" Pendant la semaine qui vient de s'écouler, les affaires au Stock Exchange ont été encore plus restreintes, si possible, que lors de la haitaine précédente.Les nombreux ordres de vente reçus d'Egypte ont été exécutés avec beancoup de difficulté, bien que portant sur des valeurs aussi bonnes et aussi sûres que la National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daïra. Il est vrai que ces ventes avaient un caractère forcé | et que les acheteurs ont profité de l'occasion | pour faire les difficiles et les avoir au meilleur compte possible. Aussi bien l'Agricole a baissé jusqu'à 8 3/8 pour remonter à 8 9/16 ; la National Bank a été ramenée jusqu'à 23 pour so relever à 23 5/8 la Daïra est tombée à 15 | pour finir à 15 178. Si ces ventes persistent par suite de la crise monétaire que semblent traverser les marchés du Caire et d'Alexandrie, il faut s'attendre à ce que des cours plus bas-- et partant exceptionnellement avantageux — aient pour effet de fixer l'attention des capitalistes sur ces placements de premier ordre et de déterminer finalement une bonne reprise.

"En effet, malgré le tapage fait sur les prétendue dangers du non moins prétendu " mouvement nationaliste" et sur la retraite de lord Cromer, tout le monde ici comprend bien qu'il n'y a rien de changé en Egypte, La stabilité du régime de l'occupation est assuré tout porte même à croire, d'aprèg des déclarations et des indications officieuses, que ce régime est appelé à être très prochainement renforcé, de manière à donner aux capitaux étrangers qui s'emploiraient sur les bords du | Nil des garanties supplémentaires de nature å les préserver contre toutes éventualités. Il n'y A donc absolument rien à appréhender sous le rapport de la sécurité : tout au contraire, celle-ci se trouvera bientot absolument garantie par certaines mesures de précaution que l'on estime inévitables dans nos milieux politiques. D'autre part, le choix de sir Eldon Gorst pour continuer la politique de lord Cromer et l'ac- 1 centuer énergiquement au besoin, est fort bien vu dans les cercles financiers.

" Il s'ensuit, par conséquent, que les difficultés dérivant, au Caire et à Alexandrie, de l'essor par trop rapide pris par les affaires financières sur ces deux places, n'inquiètent nullement les observateurs. Ces temps d'arrêt| se produisent fatalement dans tous les pays nouveaux après une longue période de prospé. rité. Ce qui est même extraordinaire, c'est que la petita: crise actuelle se soit manifesté dans des conditions aussi limitées et aussi bé- | nignes en Egypte, où le développement dans toutes les branches de l'activité a été accompli à l'aide plus ou moins seule des capitaux tirés du pays Or, on fait incontestable, c'est que cette activité ne se trouve guère enrayée du chet de quelques excès commis par la spécula

tion sur le coton, les titres et les terrains. Tout montre, au contraire, que la contrée poursuit d'un pas sûr sa marche dans la voie du progrès et de la richesse. Il n'y a donc rien de compromis et les affaires ne tarderont pas à prendre un nouvel essor, essor qui sera d'autant plus important qu il s'appuiera cette fois sur : les capitaux étrangers attirés dans le pays par la consolidation éventuelle de l'ordre de choses établi depuis 1882.

" Le marché monétaire ici continue à s'améliorer, A la liquidation de cette semaine. l'argent pour les reports jusqu'à mi-Mai a été. exceptionnellement abondant ; l'intérêt demandé par les Banques avec marge n'a été que de 3 3 4 pour cent ; plusieurs prêts se sont même effectués à 3 1/2 et plus bas. Les taux de report pour les clients ont été de 4 1/2 à 5 %. Le taux de la Banque d'Angleterre vient d'être reduit à 4 % et on s'attend à ce qu'il soit abaissé à 3 1,2 pour cent. Dans des conditions et à moins d'un déluge de nouvelles émis| sions les valeurs de Bourse doivent nécessairement se relever." :
LA BOURSE

A l'occasion des fêtes de Pâques Orthodoxes et du Cham-el Nessim, il y aura cessation d'af. faires, aux Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie, Já partir d'aujourd'hui jusqu'au Lundi 6 Mai 1907 inclusivement. | Le marché des cotons sera onvert demain matin.

div.head:
GENERAL BOTHA IN LONDON.
LABOUR QUESTION AND MINING INDUSTRY,

div.p: The representatives of the Rand mining and commercial houses and banks entertained General Botha at a banquet. The General declared that the Transvaal Government meant to do justice to the mining industry and to s make it a success, as the prosperity of the country was dependent upon it. The labour question would be dealt with after a drastic enquiry.
(Reuter)

div.head: SMALLPOX REGULATIONS.
div.p: Larnaca, 20th April, 1907. Several cases of smallpox have occurred at Limassol and a temporary isolation hospital has been erected. The epidemio appears to have been brought from Egypt, and, in con sequence, passengers arriving from that place are now required to submit to the following regulations : 11. All arrivals in Cyprus from Egypt are to be carefully inspected before being admitted to pratique, and, for further security, all persons wishing to land are to be carefully visited at the end of the pier, in accordanee with instructions issued by the chief medical officer."

2. In the event of any person being found to be affected with smallpox, the said person, - with all contacts, will be isolated, and the chief medical officer is to be immediately advised of the fact by telegram. - 3. All persons landing will be required to give to the health officer the address of the place where they propose to reside, and, should they, before the expiration of 10 days after their arrival, change their place of abode, they will give notice of such change to the health officer.
4. All snch persons shall be subject to be visited by the health officer for that purpose, within a period of 15 days from their arrival

div.head: Religious Disturbances
div.p: There has been a renewal in Nicosia of 'religious disturbances similar to those which took place a year or so ago at Famagusta. They have been due to attempts-or supposed attempts-at proselytizing on the part of certain evangelizing enthusiasts. Ai number of fines, have been imposed and some disorderly persons have been sent to prison.

div.head: The Locust Plague.
div.p: The collection of locusts has now begun, and although the nninber of locusts becomes every year less and less, and is now comparatively small, yet the locust campaign provides employment to a good many of the villagers. In the early days of the British Occupation the -"screen and pit" system was employed, and in 1882 an expenditure of £32,478 was incurred on the locust destruction operations. This outlay seems to have been productive of good results and to have been money well laid out. For some years past an adequate method adopted by the Government for keeping this plague in check, has been to pay a few piastres per oke for the living locusts, which are caught by sweeping the ground with long-handled nets or bags. The locusts, thus captured, are taken to the respective centres, temporarily established for the purpose, where they are weighed and paid for. They are then buried. The annual expenditure on this service is now abont £2.000 or even less.

div.head: Inspection of Steam Boilers
div.p: A Bill, to be introduced into the Legislative Conncil, is poblished, providing for the inspection of steam boilers. The inspectors to be oppointed thereunder will be empowered to Center any premises where there may be machinery in motion, for the purpose of inspecting and testing it. If any person is injured by the explosion of any boiler with regard to which a notice has been properly given he shall be entitled to recover compensation from the own| er unless the latter prove that the defects mentioned in the notice were duly remedied or that he was not guilty of any negligence.

div.head: "ARRIVAL OF THE DUGUAY TROUIN.
div.p: Beyrout, April 25. The French training-ship Duguay Trouin under the command of Captain Adam arrived at our port on Saturday the 20tn instant. On Sunday evening the French colony gave å brilliant ball in honour of the naval visitors in the well-known Gedai mansion that has often served for such public functions. The hall | which, as well as the adjoining appartments, were hung with oriental tapestry, looked particularly effective and the guests were numerous and included most of the smart set of Beyrout's society ; the Vali of Beyrout and the Mutessarif of Lebanon as well as most of the Consuls attended. A gay animation, such as the French alone can produce, reigned throughout the evening. Before the early hours of the morning a cold supper was served in the vast hall which was partaken of by the lingering guests who were mostly French. Mr. Ferdinand Wiet, a popular consnlar figure, did the honours of the table, and after the exchange of a few toasts proposed Mr. George Covillon, director of the Gas Company and Capitain Adam, Mr. Wiet made an eloquent speech full of patriotic sentiment. The Duguay Trouin left our port on Monday early in the afternoon.

div.head: Mouled El Nebl
div.p: To-day the Prophet's birthday was celebrated by the Moslems of Beyrout. A most disagreeable innovation has lately been introduced by the lower classes for festive display. A variety of explosives is used especially in the most crowded thoroughfares, and although these explosives are perfectly harm| less yet some detonate with gach loud reports that they are quite startling. It is surprising that the authorities should allow a custom. On a crossing of the most crowded thoroughfares of the old town triumphal arches covered with laurel and other leaves and flowers and Turkish banners were raised with the Sultan's picture | in the middle of the arch. The association of the Sovereign's picture with the Prophet's fête has a significant bearing on the question of how far the legitimacy of the Turkish Caliphate is recognized by the Moslems of the Empire.

div.head: "THE NEW SUEZ CANAL."
SCHEME DISCREDITED.
div.p: A report has been circulated to the effect that a project for the construction of a second Suez Canal, exclusively with English capital, has taken definite form, and that the grant ing of the necessary concession is only a matter of a few weeks. Further, we are told that "the project has caused the utmost chagrin in Berlin, it being believed that the Canal will relegate the Bagdad Railways to a secondary position, and constitute a serious check to German ambitions in Asia Minor.".

But the fact is the question of a second Suez Canal has taken no definite shape whatever. It is absolutely untrue that the granting of the concession is only a matter of a few weeks, and, in any case, if the proposal, which was mooted some years ago by a dis. satisfied shipowner, were ever carried out, it would in no way affect the Bagdad Railway, as will be seen from the most cursory glance at the map. The Berlin Correspondent of the : Daily Telegraph " says :

"Inquiries which I have made in the best financial circles of Berlin as to the reported concession for a new canal joining up the Mediterranean and the Red Seas produced only looks of blank amazement. One eminent authority remarked that it was probably a sister scheme to the project for building a railway to the moon."
The Paris Correspondent writes :

"After inquiry in different well-informed quarters I have not been able to obtain the slightest confirmation of the report that a second Suez Canal is soon to be constructed with English capital, the concession, according
to this rumour, being on the point of being I granted. I may remark that, in the first place,

the Suez Canal Company possesses an exclusive | monopoly, and that, in the second place, this story of a second canal 1 very old affair. The question was aired in 1865 before the agreement between the Suez Canal Company and | the British shipowners took place, and since

that date it has cropped up now and then, but not in a serious and practical manner. The | argument assigned to-day for the construction of a new canal is that it should be able to compete with the projected Bagdad Railway. But in the opinion of competent judges the present Suez Canal is amply sufficient for this purpose. I may add the remark that this ru. mour is extremely vague, as nothing is said about the route which would be followed."

div.head: A TEMPTING BAIT.
div.p: We have received a copy of a high class gravure, issued by Boyril Limited, London, entitled "A Tempting Bait," which is a reproduction of the charming oil painting that was exhibited in the Royal Academy in | 1906 by Arthur J. div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAN'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: Liverpool, April 25. Egyptian cotton on the spot continues to be very neglected, and prices are quite nominal to quotations being reduced @ plb 'for the week.

In Futures a fairly active business has been done at irregular rates, and the following are the latest values :April 9 55 July 9.49 Oct 9.39 Jan. 9.21 May 9.49 Aug. 9.45 Nov. 9.30 Feb. 9.20 June 9.49 Sept. 9.43 Dec. 9.23 March 9 201

American Futures. The Market this week has been somewhat more active. Although there have been constant fluctuations prices have generally had a rising tendency and today's closing values are 16 @ 18 points for the near, 9 @ 12 points for the summer months, and 5! @ 7 points higher for the New Crop positions, than those of last Thursday. The improvement is chiefly due to manipulation of the near positions owing to the scarcity of better grades, and to the continued unfavour. able reports regarding the prospects of the growing crop, for although rains have fallen, the temperature remains low, and a considerable amount of replanting may be necessary

Ces dépôts pourront être versés au Service | de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'heure fixée | pour l'ouverture des enchères ou bien, en séance même, mais avant la mise en adjudication de chaque lot.

Il sera procédé à la vente en commençant par les lots les plus chers, ce qui permettra | aux enchérisseurs, qui ne seront pas restés adjudicataires d'un lot, de poursuivre, s'ils le désirent, les enchères d'un autre lot, avec le même cautionnement,

Cependant, ils seront tenus de verser, en séance même, un 2nd cautionnement s'ils veulent concourir à l'adjudication d'un autre lot, au cas où ils auraient été déclarés adjudicataires d'un précédent lot, à moins qu'ils n'aient effectué un dépôt général, avant l'ouverture des enchères.
Les cautionnements seront restitués dès le | lendemain de la séance.

div.head: General Administration of Wakfs.
NOTICE.
div.p: Offers will be received at the office of the Wakfs' Delegation at Ghizeh, situated on the west of the Pont des Anglais, on the 9th day of May 1907 from 9 a,m. to midday and from | 2 to 4 p.m. for the sale by public auction of one feddan, nine kirats, and twelve sahms situated at Ghizeh, at hod Chagaret Gaddonah. This land is about 280 metres distant from the north of the Pyramid embankment and about 15 metres west of the railway line to Upper Egypt.
The upset price of the said land in block is already fixed at L.E. 2,256.

Applicants must either call personally or by proxy at the said office on the day and at the times designated above to inform them. selyes of the conditions of contract for this deal and afterwards make their offer.
All offers must be accompanied by a guarantee amounting to 20% of the sum of the said upset price.
Offers made after stated date and times or not accepted by the guarantee stipulated will not be accepted. : -

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
